01 - Stable Matching

Problem

  • Each man ranks all the women in order of preference
  • Each woman ranks all the men in order of preference
  • Each person uses all ranks from 1,...,n1, ... , n1,...,n s.t. there are no ties or incomplete lists

Male preference matrix:

w1w_1w1​ w2w_2w2​ w3w_3w3​ w4w_4w4​
m1m_1m1​ 1 2 3 4
m2m_2m2​ 4 3 1 2
m3m_3m3​ 4 3 1 2
m4m_4m4​ 3 1 4 2

Female preference matrix:

m1m_1m1​ m2m_2m2​ m3m_3m3​ m4m_4m4​
w1w_1w1​ 1 2 3 4
w2w_2w2​ 4 1 3 2
w3w_3w3​ 4 1 2 3
w4w_4w4​ 3 1 2 4
  • A Matching: each man is paired with ≤ 1 woman and vice versa

  • A Perfect Matching: each man is paired with exactly 1 woman and vice versa

    • "perfect" means one-to-one mapping
  • A Rogue Couple: a man and a woman who are not matched, but prefer each other to their current partners
  • A Stable Matching: A perfect matching without any rogue couples

Solution: Gale-Shapley Algorithm

Initially, all men and all women are freeSet S of matched pairs is emptyWhile there is at least one free man who has not proposed to every womanChoose such a man mm proposes to his highest-ranked woman w to whom he has not yet proposedIf w is freeshe becomes engaged to m s.t. S←S∪{m,w}Else if w is engaged to m′ and she prefers m to m′she becomes engaged to m s.t. S←S∪{m,w}m′ becomes free s.t. S←S\{m′,w}Otherwise, m remains freeReturn set S of engaged pairs\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{Initially, all men and all women are free} \\ &\text{Set } S \text{ of matched pairs is empty} \\ &\text{While there is at least one free man who has not proposed to every woman} \\ &\quad\text{Choose such a man } m \\ &\qquad m \text{ proposes to his highest-ranked woman } w \text{ to whom he has not yet proposed} \\ &\quad\text{If } w \text{ is free} \\ &\qquad\text{she becomes engaged to } m \text{ s.t. } S \leftarrow S \cup \{m, w\} \\ &\quad\text{Else if } w \text{ is engaged to } m' \text{ and she prefers } m \text{ to } m' \\ &\qquad\text{she becomes engaged to } m \text{ s.t. } S \leftarrow S \cup \{m, w\} \\ &\qquad m' \text{ becomes free s.t. } S \leftarrow S \backslash \{m', w\} \\ &\quad\text{Otherwise, } m \text{ remains free} \\ &\text{Return set } S \text{ of engaged pairs} \end{aligned} } ​Initially, all men and all women are freeSet S of matched pairs is emptyWhile there is at least one free man who has not proposed to every womanChoose such a man mm proposes to his highest-ranked woman w to whom he has not yet proposedIf w is freeshe becomes engaged to m s.t. S←S∪{m,w}Else if w is engaged to m′ and she prefers m to m′she becomes engaged to m s.t. S←S∪{m,w}m′ becomes free s.t. S←S\{m′,w}Otherwise, m remains freeReturn set S of engaged pairs​​

Proof of Perfection

  1. Suppose the set SSS of pairs returned by Gale-Shapley algorithm is not perfect
  2. SSS is a matching, therefore there must be at least one free man mmm
  3. mmm has proposed to all women (since the algorithm terminated)
  4. Therefore, each woman must be engaged (since she remains engaged after the first proposal to her)
  5. Therefore, all men must be engaged, contradicting ⚔️ the assumption that mmm is free
  6. That matching is perfect since the program terminated QED.

Proof of Stability

  1. Suppose SSS is not stable i.e. there are two pairs (m1,w1)(m_1, w_1)(m1​,w1​), (m2,w2)∈S(m_2, w_2) \in S(m2​,w2​)∈S s.t m1m_1m1​ prefers w2>w1w_2 > w_1w2​>w1​ and w2w_2w2​ prefers m1>m2m_1 > m_2m1​>m2​
  2. m1m_1m1​ must have proposed to w2w_2w2​ prior to w1w_1w1​ because at that stage w2w_2w2​ must have rejected m1m_1m1​; otherwise she would have been paired with w1w_1w1​, which would in turn prevent the pairing of (m2,w2)(m_2, w_2)(m2​,w2​) in a later iteration
  3. When w2w_2w2​ regected m1m_1m1​, she must have been paired with some man m3>m1m_3 > m_1m3​>m1​
  4. Since m2m_2m2​ is paired with w2w_2w2​ at termination, w2w_2w2​ must prefer m2m_2m2​ to m3m_3m3​ or m2=m3m_2 = m_3m2​=m3​
  5. This contradicts ⚔️ our conclusion (from instability) that w2w_2w2​ prefers m1>m2m_1 > m_2m1​>m2​ QED.

Observations

  • This algorithm computes a matching i.e. each woman gets pair with at most one man and vice versa
  • The man's status can alternate between being free and being engaged
  • The woman's status remains engaged after the first proposal
  • The ranking of a man's partner remains the same or goes down
  • The ranking of a woman's partner can never go down
  • The number of proposals made after kkk iterations is the best indicator of progress
  • The max number of total proposals (or iterations) that can be made is n2n^2n2
  • Always produces the same matching in which each man is paired with his best, valid partner, but each woman is paired with her worst, valid partner

02 - Analysis of Algorithms

Polynomial Time

  • Essentially brute forcing

  • e.g. brute force sorting:

    • Given nnn numbers, permute them so that they appear in increasing order
    • Try all n!n!n! permutations
    • For each permutation, check if it is sorted
    • O(nn!)O(nn!)O(nn!)
  • Desirable scaling property: when the input size doubles, the algorithm should only slow down by some constant ccc
  • An algorithm has polynomial running time if there exists constants c,d>0c,d > 0c,d>0 such that ∀n\forall n∀n, the running time is bounded by cndcn^dcnd
  • an algorithm is said to be efficient if it has a polynomial running time

Upper and Lower Bounds

  • Asymptotic Upper Bound: a function f(n)f(n)f(n) is O(g(n))O(g(n))O(g(n)) if there exists constants c>0,n0≥0c > 0, n_0 \geq 0c>0,n0​≥0 s.t. ∀n≥n0,f(n)≤cg(n)\forall n \geq n_0, \quad f(n) \leq cg(n)∀n≥n0​,f(n)≤cg(n)

    • e.g. 100nlog⁡2n100n \log_2n100nlog2​n is O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) for c=100,n0=1c = 100, n_0 = 1c=100,n0​=1

  • Asymptotic Lower Bound: a function f(n)f(n)f(n) is Ω(g(n))\Omega(g(n))Ω(g(n)) if there exist constants c>0,n0≥0c > 0, n_0 \geq 0c>0,n0​≥0 s.t. ∀n≥n0,f(n)≥cg(n)\forall n \geq n_0, \quad f(n) \geq cg(n)∀n≥n0​,f(n)≥cg(n)

    • e.g. n10log⁡2n\frac{n}{10}\log_2 n10n​log2​n is Ω(n)\Omega(n)Ω(n) for c=1,n0=1024c = 1, n_0 = 1024c=1,n0​=1024

In general, we attempt to find a sufficiently large n0n_0n0​ such that our upper and lower bounds are satisfied.

  • Asymptotic Tight Bound: a function f(n)f(n)f(n) is Θ(g(n))\Theta(g(n))Θ(g(n)) if f(n)f(n)f(n) is O(g(n))O(g(n))O(g(n)) and f(n)f(n)f(n) is Ω(g(n))\Omega(g(n))Ω(g(n))

Transitively:

  • if f=O(g)f = O(g)f=O(g) and g=O(h)g = O(h)g=O(h), then f=O(h)f = O(h)f=O(h)
  • if f=Ω(g)f = \Omega(g)f=Ω(g) and g=Ω(h)g = \Omega(h)g=Ω(h), then f=Ω(h)f = \Omega(h)f=Ω(h)
  • if f=Θ(g)f = \Theta(g)f=Θ(g) and g=Θ(h)g = \Theta(h)g=Θ(h), then f=Θ(h)f = \Theta(h)f=Θ(h)

Additively:

  • if f=O(h)f = O(h)f=O(h) and g=O(h)g = O(h)g=O(h), then f+g=O(h)f + g = O(h)f+g=O(h)
  • Similar statements hold for lower and tight bounds
  • if kkk is a constant and there are kkk functions: fi=O(h),1≤i≤kf_i = O(h), 1\leq i \leq kfi​=O(h),1≤i≤k
f1+f2+...+fk=O(h)\begin{aligned} f_1 + f_2 + ... + f_k = O(h) \end{aligned}f1​+f2​+...+fk​=O(h)​
  • if f=O(g)f = O(g)f=O(g), then f+g=Θ(g)f + g = \Theta(g)f+g=Θ(g)

03 - Review of Graphs and Priority Queues

Priority Queues: Motivation

Sorting

  • Instance: Nonempty list [x1,x2,…,xn][x_1, x_2, \mathellipsis, x_n][x1​,x2​,…,xn​] of integers
  • Solution: A permutation [y1,y2,…,yn][y_1, y_2, \mathellipsis, y_n][y1​,y2​,…,yn​] of x1,x2,…,xnx_1, x_2, \mathellipsis, x_nx1​,x2​,…,xn​ such that yi≤yi+1y_i \leq y_{i+1}yi​≤yi+1​ for all 1≤i<n1 \leq i < n1≤i<n$

Possible algorithm:

  • insert each number into some data structure DDD
  • Repeatedly find the smallest number in DDD, output it, and remove it
  • To get O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) running time, each "find minimum" step and each remove step must additively take O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn)

Priority Queues

  • Store a set SSS of elements where each element vvv has a priority value key(v)key(v)key(v)
  • smaller key values = higher priorities

  • Supported operations:

    • find element with smallest key
    • remove smallest element
    • insert an element
    • delete an element
    • update the key of an element
  • element deletion and key update require knowledge of the position of the element in the priority
  • combines benefits of both lists and sorted arrays
  • balanced binary tree
  • heapy order. For every element vvv at a node iii, the element www at iii's parent satisfies key(w)≤key(v)key(w) \leq key(v)key(w)≤key(v)
  • Each node's key is at least as large as its parent's

  • storing nodes of the heap in an array:

    • Node at index iii has children at indices 2i2i2i and 2i+12i+12i+1, with a parent at index ⌊i2⌋\lfloor \frac{i}{2} \rfloor⌊2i​⌋
    • index 1 is the root
    • if 2i>n2i > n2i>n, where nnn is the current number of elements in the heap, the node at index iii is a leaf

Inserting an Element: Heapify-up

  • insert a new element at index n+1n+1n+1
  • Fix heap order using Heapify-up(H, n+1)
Heapify-up(H, i)If i>1 thenlet j=parent(i) =⌊i2⌋If key[H[i]] < key[H[j]] then swap entries H[i], H[j]Heapify-up(H, j)\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{Heapify-up(H, i)} \\ &\text{If } i > 1 \text{ then} \\ &\quad\text{let } j = \text{parent(i) } = \lfloor \frac{i}{2} \rfloor \\ &\quad\text{If key[H[i]] < key[H[j]] then } \\ &\qquad\text{swap entries H[i], H[j]} \\ &\qquad\text{Heapify-up(H, j)} \\ \end{aligned} } ​Heapify-up(H, i)If i>1 thenlet j=parent(i) =⌊2i​⌋If key[H[i]] < key[H[j]] then swap entries H[i], H[j]Heapify-up(H, j)​​

Proof of Running Time Complexity for Heapify-up(i)

  • each invocation decreases the second argument by a factor of at least 2
  • after kkk invocations, argument is at most i2k\frac{i}{2^k}2ki​
  • Therefore i2k≥1\frac{i}{2^k} \geq 12ki​≥1 which implies that k≤log⁡2ik \leq \log_2 ik≤log2​i therefore heapify up is O(log⁡i)O(\log i)O(logi)

Deleting an Element: Heapify-down

  • Suppose HHH has n+1n+1n+1 elements
  • Delete element H[i]H[i]H[i] moving element at H[n+1]H[n+1]H[n+1] to H[i]H[i]H[i]
  • If element at H[i]H[i]H[i] is too small, fix the heap order using Heapify-up(H, i)
  • If element at H[i]H[i]H[i] is too large, fix heap order using Heapify-down(H, i)
Heapify-down(H, i)let n=length(H)If 2i>n thenTerminate with H unchangedElse If 2i<n thenLet Left, Right =2i,2i+1Let j be the index that minimizes key[H[Left]] and key[H[Right]]Else 2i=n thenLet j=2iIf key[H[j]] < key[H[i]] then swap the entries H[i] and H[j]Heapify-down(h,j)\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{Heapify-down(H, i)} \\ &\text{let } n = length(H) \\ &\text{If } 2i > n \text{ then} \\ &\quad\text{Terminate with } H \text { unchanged} \\ &\text{Else If } 2i < n \text{ then} \\ &\quad\text{Let Left, Right } = 2i, 2i+1 \\ &\quad\text{Let } j \text{ be the index that minimizes key[H[Left]] and key[H[Right]]} \\ &\text{Else } 2i = n \text{ then} \\ &\quad\text{Let } j = 2i \\ &\text{If key[H[j]] < key[H[i]] then } \\ &\quad\text{swap the entries H[i] and H[j]} \\ &\quad\text{Heapify-down(h,j)} \\ \end{aligned} } ​Heapify-down(H, i)let n=length(H)If 2i>n thenTerminate with H unchangedElse If 2i<n thenLet Left, Right =2i,2i+1Let j be the index that minimizes key[H[Left]] and key[H[Right]]Else 2i=n thenLet j=2iIf key[H[j]] < key[H[i]] then swap the entries H[i] and H[j]Heapify-down(h,j)​​

Proof of Running Time Complexity for Heapify-down(i)

  • Each invocation increases is second argument by a factor of at least 2
  • after kkk invocations arguments must be at least i2k≤ni2^k \leq ni2k≤n, which impleies that k≤log⁡2nik \leq \log_2 \frac{n}{i}k≤log2​in​
  • Therefore running time is O(log⁡2ni)O(\log_2 \frac{n}{i})O(log2​in​)

Sorting

  • Instance: Nonempty list [x1,x2,…,xn][x_1, x_2, \mathellipsis, x_n][x1​,x2​,…,xn​] of integers
  • Solution: A permutation [y1,y2,…,yn][y_1, y_2, \mathellipsis, y_n][y1​,y2​,…,yn​] of x1,x2,…,xnx_1, x_2, \mathellipsis, x_nx1​,x2​,…,xn​ such that yi≤yi+1y_i \leq y_{i+1}yi​≤yi+1​ for all 1≤i<n1 \leq i < n1≤i<n$

Final algorithm:

  • Insert each number in a priority queue HHH
  • Repeatedly find the smallest number in HHH, output it, and delete it from HHH

Thus, each insertion and deletion take O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn) for a total running time of O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn)

Graphs: Motivation

  • Contact tracing hahaaaaa

Taxonomy of a Graph

  • comprised of vertices and (directed / undirect) edges, they can form face.
  • Euler Path: Only possible if the number of nodes with odd degree is at most 2

  • Formally, an Undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) where V,EV, EV,E are sets of vertices and edges with E⊆V×VE \subseteq V \times VE⊆V×V

    • Elements of EEE are unordered pairs
    • Edge(u,v)Edge(u, v)Edge(u,v) is incident on u,vu,vu,v meaning u,vu,vu,v are neighbors of one another
    • Exactly one edge between any pair of nodes
    • GGG contains no self loops, i.e. no edges of the from (u,u)(u,u)(u,u)

  • Formally, an directed graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) where V,EV, EV,E are sets of vertices and edges with E⊆V×VE \subseteq V \times VE⊆V×V

    • Elements of EEE are ordered pairs
    • e=(u,v)e = (u, v)e=(u,v) where uuu is the tail of the edge eee, vvv is the head, and we can say that eee is directed from uuu to vvv
    • A pair of nodes may be connected by two directed edges (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) and (v,u)(v,u)(v,u)
    • GGG contains no self loops
  • A v1−vkv_1 - v_kv1​−vk​ path in an undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E) is a sequence of PPP nodes v1,v2,…,vk−1,vk;vk∈Vv_1, v_2, \mathellipsis, v_{k-1}, v_k; v_k \in Vv1​,v2​,…,vk−1​,vk​;vk​∈V s.t. every consecutive pair of nodes vi;vi+1,1≤i<kv_i; v_{i+1}, 1 \leq i < kvi​;vi+1​,1≤i<k is connected by an edge EEE
  • a path is simple if all its nodes are distinct
  • a cycle is a path where k>2k>2k>2, the first k−1k-1k−1 nodes are distinct and v1=vkv_1 = v_kv1​=vk​
  • An undirected graph GGG is connected if, for every pair of nodes u,v∈Vu,v \in Vu,v∈V, there is a path from uuu to vvv in GGG
  • The distance d(u,v)d(u,v)d(u,v) between nodes u,vu,vu,v is the minimum number of edges in any u−vu-vu−v path
  • The connected component of GGG containing sss is the set of all nodes uuu such that there is an s−us-us−u path in GGG

Computing Connected Components

04 - Linear-Time Graph Algorithms

Bipartite Graphs

  • A graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) is bipartite if VVV can be partitioned into two subsets X,YX,YX,Y such that every edge in EEE has one endpoint in XXX and one in YYY

    • X×X∩E=∅X \times X \cap E = \emptysetX×X∩E=∅ and Y×Y∩E=∅Y \times Y \cap E = \emptysetY×Y∩E=∅
    • Color the nodes in XXX red and the nodes in YYY blue. No edge in EEE connects nodes of the same graph
  • no cycle with an odd number of nodes is bipartite, similarly all cycles of even length are bipartite
  • Therefore, if a graph is bipartite, then it cannot contain a cycle of odd length

Algorithm for Testing Bipartite

  • Assume GGG is connected, otherwise apply the algorithm to each connected component separately
  • Pick an arbitrary node sss and color it red.
  • Color all it's neighbors blue. Color the uncolored neighbors of these nodes red, and so on till all nodes are colored
  • Check if every edge has endpoints of different colours

more formally:

  1. Run BFS on GGG. Maintain an array for the color
  2. When we add a node vvv to a layer iii, set color[i]\text{color[i]}color[i] to red if iii is even, blue of odd
  3. At the end of BFS, scan all the edges to check if there is any edge both of whose endpoints received the same color

Running time is linear proprotional to the size of the graph: O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) since we do a constant amount of work per node in addition to the time spent by BFS.

Proof of Correctness of a "two-colorable" algorithm

Need to prove that if the algorithm says GGG is bipartite, then it is actually bipartite AND need to prove that if GGG is not bipartite, can we determine why?

  • Let GGG be a graph and let L0,L1,…,LkL_0, L_1, \mathellipsis, L_kL0​,L1​,…,Lk​ be the layers produced by the BFS, starting at node sss. Then exactly one of the following statements is true:

    • No edge of GGG joins two nodes in the same layer: Bipartite since nodes in the even laters can be colored red and those in odd blue
    • There is an edge of GGG that joins two nodes in the same layer: Not Bipartite
    • ∣Li−Lj∣=1,∀L∈BFS| L_i - L_j | = 1, \quad \forall L \in BFS∣Li​−Lj​∣=1,∀L∈BFS

05 - Greedy Algorithms

  • Greedy algorithms: make the best current choice without looking back. Assume the choices made prior were perfect

Example Problem: Interval Scheduling

  • At an amusement park, want to compute the largest number of rides you can be on in one day
  • Input: start and end time of each ride
  • Constraint: cannot be in two places at one time
  • Instance: nonempty set {(s(i),f(i)),1≤i≤n}\{(s(i), f(i)), 1 \leq i \leq n\}{(s(i),f(i)),1≤i≤n} of start and finish times of nnn jobs
  • Solution: The largest subset of mutually compatibe jobs
  • Two jobs are compatible if they do not overlap
  • Problem models the situation where you havea resource, a set of fixed jobs, and you want to schedule as many jobs as possible
  • For any input set of jobs, the algorithm must provably compute the largest set of compatible jobs (measured by interval count, not cumulative interval length)

Template for a Greedy Algorithm

  • Process jobs in some order. Add next job to the result if it is compatible with the jobs already in the result

  • key question: in what order should we process job?

    • earliest start time: increasing order of start time s(i)s(i)s(i)
    • earliest finish time: increasing order of start time f(i)f(i)f(i)
    • shortest interval: increasing order of f(i)−s(i)f(i) - s(i)f(i)−s(i)
    • fewest conflicts: increasing order of the number of conflicting jobs

Earliest Finish Time

  • the most optimal general solution
Initially let R be the set of all jobs, and let A be emptyWhile R is not yet emptyChoose a job i∈R that has the smallest finishing time Add request i to ADelete all jobs from R that are not compatible with job iReturn the set A as the set of accepted/scheduled jobs\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{Initially let } R \text{ be the set of all jobs, and let } A \text{ be empty} \\ &\text{While } R \text{ is not yet empty}\\ &\quad\text{Choose a job } i \in R \text{ that has the smallest finishing time } \\ &\quad\text{Add request } i \text{ to } A \\ &\quad\text{Delete all jobs from } R \text{ that are not compatible with job } i \\ &\text{Return the set } A \text{ as the set of accepted/scheduled jobs} \\ \end{aligned} } ​Initially let R be the set of all jobs, and let A be emptyWhile R is not yet emptyChoose a job i∈R that has the smallest finishing time Add request i to ADelete all jobs from R that are not compatible with job iReturn the set A as the set of accepted/scheduled jobs​​

  • Store starting time of jobs in an array SSS

Scheduling to Minimize Lateness

  • Suppose a job iii has a length t(i)t(i)t(i) and a deadline d(i)d(i)d(i)
  • want to schedule all nnn jobs on one resource
  • Goal is to assign a starting time s(i)s(i)s(i) to each job such that each job is delayed as little as possible
  • A job iii is delayed if f(i)>d(i)f(i) > d(i)f(i)>d(i); the lateness of job is max⁡(0,f(i)−d(i))\max(0, f(i) - d(i))max(0,f(i)−d(i))

    • the largest of each job's lateness values

Minimizing Lateness

  • Instance: Set {(t(i),d(i)),1≤i≤n}\{ (t(i), d(i)), 1 \leq i \leq n \}{(t(i),d(i)),1≤i≤n} of lengths of deadlines of nnn jobs
  • Solution: Set {s(i),1≤i≤n}\{ s(i), 1 \leq i \leq n \}{s(i),1≤i≤n} such that max⁡1≤i≤n(max⁡(0,f(i)−d(i)))\max \limits_{1 \leq i \leq n}(\max(0, f(i) - d(i)))1≤i≤nmax​(max(0,f(i)−d(i))) is as small as possible

Template for Greedy Algorithm

Proof of Earliest Deadline Optimality

Inversions

  • A schedule has an inversion if a job iii with a deadline d(i)d(i)d(i) is scheduled before another job jjj with an earlier deadline d(j)d(j)d(j) i.e. d(j)<d(i),s(i)<s(j)d(j) < d(i), s(i) < s(j)d(j)<d(i),s(i)<s(j)

    • if two jobs have the same deadline, they cannot cause an inversion
  • in nnn jobs, the maximum amount of inversion is (n2)n \choose 2(2n​)
  • Claim: if a schedule has and inversion, then there must be a pair of jobs i,ji, ji,j such that jjj is scheduled immediately after iii and d(j)<d(i)d(j) < d(i)d(j)<d(i)

Proof of Local Inversion

  • If we have an inversion between l,ml, ml,m s.t. s(l)<s(m),d(l)>d(m)s(l) < s(m), d(l) > d(m)s(l)<s(m),d(l)>d(m), then we can find some inverted i,ji,ji,j scheduled between l,ml,ml,m
  • This is because: in a list where each element is greater than the last (in terms of deadline), then the list is sorted.
  • The contrapositive of this is: if a list is unsorted, then there are two adjacent elements that are unsorted.

Properties of Schedules

  • Claim 1: The algorithm produces a schedule with no inversion and no idle time (i.e. jobs are tightly packed)

  • Claim 2: All schedules (produced from the same input) with no inversions have the same lateness

    • Case 1: All jobs have distinct deadlines. There is a unique schedule with no inversions and no idle time.
    • Case 2: Some jobs have the same deadline. Ordering of the jobs does not change the maximum lateness of these jobs.
  • Claim 3: There is an optimal schedule with no idle time.

  • Claim 4: There is an optimal schedule with no inversions and no idle time.

    • Start with an optimal schedule OOO (that may have inversions) and use an exchange argument to convert OOO into a schedule that satisfies Claim 4 and has lateness not larger than OOO.
    • If OOO has an inversion, let i,ji, ji,j be consecutive inverted jobs in OOO. After swapping i,ji, ji,j we get a schedule O′O'O′ with one less inversion.
    • Claim: The lateness of O′O'O′ is no larger than the lateness of OOO
    • It is sufficient to prove the last item, since after (n2)n \choose 2(2n​) swaps, we obtain a schedule with no inversions whose lateness is no larger than that of OOO
    • In OOO, assume each job rrr is scheduled for the interval [s(r),f(r)][s(r), f(r)][s(r),f(r)] and has lateness l(r)\mathcal l(r)l(r). For O′O'O′, let the lateness of rrr be l′(r)l'(r)l′(r)
    • Claim: l′(k)=l(k),∀k≠i,jl'(k) = l(k), \quad \forall k \neq i,jl′(k)=l(k),∀k​=i,j
    • Claim: l′(j)=l(j)l'(j) = l(j)l′(j)=l(j),
    • Claim: l′(j)≤l(j)l'(j) \leq l(j)l′(j)≤l(j) because l′(j)=f(j)−di≤f(j)−dj=l(j)l'(j) = f(j) - d_i \leq f(j) - d_j = l(j)l′(j)=f(j)−di​≤f(j)−dj​=l(j)

    • N.B. common mistakes with exchange arguments:

      • Wrong: start with algorithm's schedule A and argue it cannot be improved by swapping two jobs
      • Correct: Start with an arbitrary schedule O (which can be optimal) and argue that O can be converted into a schedule that is essentially the same as A without increasing lateness
      • Wrong: Swap two jobs that are not neighboring in OOO. Pitfall is that the completion time of all intervining jobs then changes
      • Corrext: Show that an inversion exists between two neighboring jobs and swap them
  • Claim 5: The greedy algorithm produces an optimal schedule, follows from 1, 2, 4

Summary

  • Greedy algorithms make local decisions

  • Three strategies:

    • Greedy algorithm stays ahead - Show that after each step in the greedy algorithm, its solution is at least as good as that produced by any other algorithm
    • Structural bound - First, discover a property that must be satisfied by every possible solution. Then show that the (greedy) algorithm produces a solution with this property
    • Exchange argument - Transform the optimal solution in steps into the solution by the greedy algorithm without worsening the quality of the optimal solution

06 - Greedy Graph Algorithms

The Shortest Path Problem

  • G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) is a connected, directed graph. Each edge has a length l(e)≥0l(e) \geq 0l(e)≥0
  • length of a path PPP us the sum of the lengths of the edges in PPP
  • Goal: compute the shortest path from a specified start node sss to every other node in the graph
  • Instace: A directed graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E), a function I:E→R+I: E \rightarrow \reals^+I:E→R+ and a node s∈Vs \in Vs∈V
  • Solution: A set {Pu,u∈V}\{P_u, u \in V\}{Pu​,u∈V} of paths, where PuP_uPu​ is the shortest path in GGG from sss to uuu

Generalizing BFS

  • If all edges have the same wight, or distance, BFS would work, processing nodes in order of distance.

  • What if the graph has integer edge weights, can we make the graph unwieghted?

    • yes, placing dummy edges and nodes to pad out lengths > 1 at the expense of memory and running time
    • Edge weight of www gets w−1w - 1w−1 nodes
    • Size of the graph (and therefore runtime) becomes m+n+∑e∈El(e)m + n + \sum_{e \in E} l(e)m+n+∑e∈E​l(e). Pseudo-polynomial time depending on input values

Dijkstra's Algorithm

  • Fmaous for pointing out the harm of the goto command, in doing so developed the shortest path algorithm
  • Like BFS: explore nodes in non-increasing order of distance sss. Once a node is explored, its distance is fixed
  • Unlike BFS: Layers are not uniform, edges are explored by evaluating candidates by edge wight
  • For each unexplored node, determine "best" preceding explored node. Record shortest path length only through explored nodes
  • Like BFS: Record previous node in path, and build a tree.

Formally:

  • Maintain a set SSS of explored nodes

    • For each node u∈Su \in Su∈S, compute d(u)d(u)d(u), which (we will prove, invariant) is the length of the shortest path from sss to uuu
    • For each node x∉Sx \notin Sx∈/​S, matain a value d′(x)d'(x)d′(x), which is the length of the shortest path from sss to xxx using only the nodes in SSS and xxx itself
  • Greedily add a node vvv to SSS that has the smallest value of d′(v)d'(v)d′(v)

Network Design

  • want to connect a set of nodes using a set of edges with certain properties
  • Input is usually a graph, and the desired network (output) should use a subset of edges in the graph
  • Example: connect all nodes using a cycle of shortest total length. This problem is the NP-complete traveling salesman problem

Minimum Spanning Tree (MST)

  • Given an undirected graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) with a cost c(e)>0c(e) > 0c(e)>0 associated with each edge e∈Ee \in Ee∈E.
  • Find a subset TTT of edges such that the graph (V,T)(V,T)(V,T) is connected and the cost ∑e∈Tc(e)\sum_{e \in T} c(e)∑e∈T​c(e) is as small as possible
  • Instance: An undirected graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) and a function c:E→R+c: E \rightarrow \R^+c:E→R+
  • Solution: A set T⊆ET \sube ET⊆E of edges such that (V,T)(V, T)(V,T) is connected and the cost ∑e∈Tc(e)\sum_{e \in T} c(e)∑e∈T​c(e) is as small as possible
  • Claim: if TTT is a minimum-cost solution to this problem, then (V,T)(V,T)(V,T) is a tree
  • A subset TofET of ETofE is a spanning tree of GGG if (V,T)(V, T)(V,T) is a tree

Characterizing MSTs

  • Does the edge of smallest cost belong to an MST? Yes

    • Wrong proof: Because Kruskal's algorithm adds it.
    • Right proof: tbd

  • Which edges must belong to an MST?

    • What happens when we delete an edge from an MST?
    • MST breaks up into sub-trees
    • Which edge should we add to join them?

  • Which edges cannot belong to an MST?

    • What happens when we add an edge to an MST?
    • We obtain a cycle
    • Which edge in the cycle can we be sure does not belong to an MST

Greedy Algorithm for the MST Problem

  • Template: process edges in some order. Add an edge to TTT if tree property is not violated.

    • increasing cost order: Process edges in increasing order of cost. Discard an edge if it creates a cycle – Kruskal's
    • Dijkstra-like: Start from a node sss and grow TTT outward from sss: add the node that can attached most cheaply to current tree – Prim's
    • Decreasing cost order: Delete edges in order of decreasing cost as long as graph remains connected – Reverse-Delete
    • each of these works
    • Simplifying assumption: all edge costs are distinct

Graph Cuts

  • a cut in a graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) is a set of edges whose removal disconnects the graph (into two or more connected components)
  • Every set S⊂VS \sub VS⊂V (SSS cannot be empty or the entire set VVV) has a corresponding cut: cut(SSS) is the set of edges (v,w) such that v∈S,w∈V−Sv \in S, w \in V - Sv∈S,w∈V−S
  • cut(SSS) is a "cut" because deleting the edges in cut(SSS) disconnects SSS from V−SV - SV−S

  • Claim: for every S⊂V,S≠∅S \sub V, S \neq \emptyS⊂V,S​=∅, every MST contains the cheapest edge in cut(S(S(S)

    • will have to proof by contradiction using exchange argument

Proof of Cut Property of MSTs

  • Negation of the desired property: There is a set S⊂VS \sub VS⊂V and an MST TTT such that TTT does not contaian the cheapest edge in cut(SSS)
  • Proof strategy: If TTT does not contain eee, show that there is a tree with a smaller cost than TTT that contains eee.

  • Wrong proof:

    • Since TTT is spanning, it must contain some edge e.g. fff in cut($S)
    • T−{f}∪{e}T - \{f\} \cup \{e\}T−{f}∪{e} has smaller cost than TTT but may not be a spanning tree

  • Correct proof:

    • Add eee to TTT forming a cycle
    • This cycle must contain an edge e′e'e′ in cut(SSS)
    • T−{e′}∪{e}T - \{e'\} \cup \{e\}T−{e′}∪{e} has smaller cost than TTT and is a spanning tree

Kruskal's Algorithm

  • Start with an empty set TTT of edges
  • Process edges in EEE in increasing order of cost
  • Add the next edge eee to TTT only if adding eee does not create a cycle. Discard eee otherwise
  • Note: at any iteration, TTT may contain several connected components and each node in VVV is in some component

  • Claim: Kruskal's algorithm outputs an MST

    • For every edge eee added, demonstrate the existence of a set S⊂VS \sub VS⊂V (and V−SV - SV−S) such that eee and SSS satisfy the cut property, i.e.e, the cheapest edge in cut(S)cut(S)cut(S)
    • If e=(u,v)e = (u,v)e=(u,v), let SSS be the set of nodes connected to uuu in the current graph TTT
    • Why is eee the cheapest edge in cut(SSS) - because we process them in increasing order of cost

    • Prove that the algorithm computes a spanning tree

      • (V,T)(V,T)(V,T) contains no cycles by construction
      • If (V,T)(V,T)(V,T) is not connected, then there exists a subset SSS of nodes not connected to V−SV-SV−S. What is the contradiction?

Implementing Kruskal's Algorithm

  • start with an empty set TTT of edges
  • Process edges in EEE in icreasing order of cost
  • Add the next edge eee to TTT only if adding eee does not create a cycle
  • Sorting edges takes O(mlog⁡n)O(m \log n)O(mlogn) time

  • Key question: "Does adding e=(u,v)e = (u,v)e=(u,v) to TTT create a cycle?

    • Maintain set of connected components of TTT
    • Find(u)Find(u)Find(u): return the name of the connected component of TTT that uuu belongs to
    • Union(A,B)Union(A,B)Union(A,B): merge connected componenets A, B

  • How many UnionUnionUnion invocations? n−1n-1n−1

Minimum Bottleneck Spanning Tree (MBST)

  • MST minimises the total cost of the spanning network

  • Consider another network design criterion

    • build a network connext all cities in mountainous region, but ensure the highest elevation is as low as possible
    • total road length is not a criterion
  • Idea: compute an MST in which the edge with the highest cost is as cheap as possible
  • In an undirected graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E), let (V,T)(V,T)(V,T) be a spanning tree. The bottleneck edge in TTT is the edge with the largest fcost in TTT
  • Instance: An an undirected graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) such that V,TV,TV,T is a spanning tree
  • Solution: A Set T⊆ET \sube ET⊆E of edges such that (V,T)(V,T)(V,T) is a spanning tree and there is no spanning tree in GGG with a cheaper bottleneck

Is every MST and MBST, or vice versa?

  • If a tree is an MBST, it might not be an MST
  • If a tree is an MST, it will be an MBST

Proof:

  • Let TTT be the MST, and let T′T'T′ be a spanning tree with a cheaper bottleneck edge.
  • Let eee be the bottleneck edge in TTT
  • Every edge in T′T'T′ has lower cost than eee
  • Adding eee to T′T'T′ creates a cycle consisting only of edges, where eee is the costliest edge in the cycle
  • Since eee is the costliest edge in this cycle, by the cycle property, eee cannot belong to any MST, which contradicts the fact that TTT is an MST

08 - Divide and Conquer Algorithms

Mergesort

  • Instance: nonempty list L=x1,x2,...,xnL = x_1, x_2, ..., x_nL=x1​,x2​,...,xn​ integers
  • Solution: A permutation y1,y2,...,yny_1, y_2, ..., y_ny1​,y2​,...,yn​ of LLL such that yi≤yi+1y_i \leq y_{i+1}yi​≤yi+1​ for all 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n

  • Mergesort is a divide and conquer algorithm for sorting

    • Partition LLL into two lists A,BA, BA,B of sizes ⌊n/2⌋,⌈n/2⌉\lfloor n/2 \rfloor, \lceil n/2 \rceil⌊n/2⌋,⌈n/2⌉
    • Recursively sort A,BA, BA,B,
    • Merge the sorted lists A,BA,BA,B into a sorted list

Merging Two Sorted Lists

  • Maintain a current pointer for each list
  • initialize each pointed to the front of the list

  • While both lists are non-empty:

    • let ai,bia_i, b_iai​,bi​ be the elements pointed to by each pointer
    • append the smaller of the two to the output list
    • advance the current pointer in the list that the smaller element belonged to
  • append the rest of the non-empty list to the output
  • Running time of this algorithm is O(k+l)O(k+l)O(k+l), k=len(L)k = len(L)k=len(L)

    Counting Inversions

  • Motivation:

    • collaborative filtering - match one user's preferences to those of other users
    • Meta-search engines - merge results of multiple search engines into a better search results

  • Two rankings of things are very similar if they have few inversions

    • Two rankings a,ba,ba,b have an inversion if there exists i,ji,ji,j such that i<ji < ji<j but ai>aja_i > a_jai​>aj​
    • the number of inversions sss is a measure of the difference between the rankings
  • Kendall's rank correlation of two lists of numbers is 1−2sn(n−1)\frac{1-2s}{n(n-1)}n(n−1)1−2s​
  • Instance: A list L=x1,xs,...,xnL = x_1, x_s, ..., x_nL=x1​,xs​,...,xn​ of distinct integers between 1,n1, n1,n
  • Solution: The number of pairs (i,j),1<i<j≤n(i,j), 1 < i < j \leq n(i,j),1<i<j≤n s.t. xi>xjx_i > x_jxi​>xj​

  • How many inversions can there be in a list of nnn numbers?

    • n(n−1)2=Ω(n2)\frac{n(n-1)}{2} = \Omega(n^2)2n(n−1)​=Ω(n2) since every inversion involves a pair of two numbers
  • Sorting removes all inversion in O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) time. Can we modify mergesort to count inversions?

  • Candidate algorithm:

    • Partition LLL into A,BA,BA,B of size n/2n/2n/2 each
    • Recursively count the number of inversions in AAA and sort AAA
    • Recursively count the number of inversions in BBB and sort BBB
    • Count to number of inversions involving on element in AAA and one element in BBB

"Conquer" step

  • Given lists A=a1,a2,...,amA = a_1, a_2, ..., a_mA=a1​,a2​,...,am​ and B=b1,b2,...,bmB = b_1, b_2, ..., b_mB=b1​,b2​,...,bm​, compute the number of pairs aia_iai​ and bjb_jbj​ s.t. ai>bja_i > b_jai​>bj​

    • This step is much easier if A,BA,BA,B are sorted

  • Merge-And-Count Procedure:

    • Maintain a current pointer for each list
    • Maintain a variable count initialised to 0
    • Initialize each pointer to the front of each list

    • While both lists are non-empty

      • Let ai,bja_i, b_jai​,bj​ be the elements pointed to by the current pointers
      • Append the smaller of the two to the output list
      • Do something clever in O(1)O(1)O(1) time --> if bj<aib_j < a_ibj​<ai​ then count += m - i, since every element following ai+a_{i^+}ai+​ will also be an inversion with bjb_jbj​
      • Advance the current pointer of the list containing the smaller list
    • Append the rest of the non-empty list to the output
    • Return count and the merged list
    • O(m)O(m)O(m)

Sort and Count

If the list has one elementThere are no inversions and the list is sorted Divide the list into two halvesA←list⌊n/2⌋B←list⌈n/2⌉\boxed{ \begin{aligned} &\text{If the list has one element} \\ &\quad\text{There are no inversions and the list is sorted } \\ &\text{Divide the list into two halves} \\ &\quad A \leftarrow list \lfloor n/2 \rfloor \\ &\quad B \leftarrow list \lceil n/2 \rceil \\ \end{aligned} } ​If the list has one elementThere are no inversions and the list is sorted Divide the list into two halvesA←list⌊n/2⌋B←list⌈n/2⌉​​

Proof of Correctness

  • Proof by induction: Strategy

    • a) every inversion in the data is counted exactly once
    • b) no non-inversions are counted
  • Base case: n=1n = 1n=1
  • Inductive Hypothesis: Algorithm counts number of inversion correctly for all sets of n−1n-1n−1 or fewer numbers

  • Inductive Step: Consider an arbitrary inversion, i.e., any pair k,lk,lk,l such that k<lk < lk<l but xk>xlx_k > x_lxk​>xl​. When is this inversion counted by the algorithm

    • k,l≤⌊n/2⌋:xk,xl∈Ak,l \leq \lfloor n/2 \rfloor: x_k, x_l \in Ak,l≤⌊n/2⌋:xk​,xl​∈A, counted in rAr_ArA​ but the inductive hypothesis
    • k,l≥⌈n/2⌉:xk,xl∈Bk,l \geq \lceil n/2 \rceil: x_k, x_l \in Bk,l≥⌈n/2⌉:xk​,xl​∈B, counted in rBr_BrB​ but the inductive hypothesis
    • k≤⌊n/2⌋,l≥⌈n/2⌉:xk∈A,xl∈Bk \leq \lfloor n/2 \rfloor, l \geq \lceil n/2 \rceil: x_k \in A, x_l \in Bk≤⌊n/2⌋,l≥⌈n/2⌉:xk​∈A,xl​∈B. Is this inversion counted by Merge-And-Count? Yes: when xlx_lxl​ is output to the final list is when we count this inversion
    • Why is no non-inversion counted? When xlx_lxl​ is output, it is smaller than all remaining elements in AAA since AAA is sorted

09 - Dynamic Programming

Motivation

  • Goal: design efficient polynomial time algs

  • Greedy:

    • pro: natural approach to algorith design
    • con: many greedy approaches; only some may work
    • con: many problems for which no greedy approach is known

  • Divide and conquer

    • pro: simple to develop algorithm skeleton
    • con: conquer step can be very hard to implement efficiently
    • con: usually reduces time for a problem known to be solvable in polynomial time

  • Dynamic Programming

    • more powerful than greedy and divide and conquer strategies
    • implicitly explore the space of all possible solutions
    • solve multiple sub-problems and build up correct solutions to larger and larger subproblems
    • careful analysis needed to ensure number of sub-problems solved is polynomial in the size of the input

Example: Greedy Scheduling, but using a DP approach

  • Input: start and end time of day: Set {(s(i),f(i)),1≤i≤n}\{(s(i), f(i)), 1 \leq i \leq n\}{(s(i),f(i)),1≤i≤n}
  • Contraint: cannot be in two places at one time
  • Goal: maximum number of rides you can go on: largest subset of mutually compatible jobs
  • EFT: sort jobs in order of increasing finish time, and add compatible jobs to the set

  • Use DP to solve a Weighted Interval Scheduling problem:

    • Instance: nonempty set {(sifi),1≤i≤n}\{(s_i f_i), 1 \leq i \leq n\}{(si​fi​),1≤i≤n} and a weight vi≥0v_i \geq 0vi​≥0 associated with each job
    • Solution: A set SSS of mutually compatible jobs such that the value ∑i∈Svi\sum_{i \in S} v_i∑i∈S​vi​ is maximized
    • Greedy algorithm can produce arbitrarily bad results for this problem depending on weights

Detour: Binomial Identity

      1
    1   1
  1   2   1
1   3   3   1
  • sum of a row = 2n2^n2n
  • Value of a cell kkk in row nnn = (nk)n \choose k(kn​)
  • each element is the sum of the two elements above it
  • (nr)=(n−1r−1)+(n−1r){n \choose r} = {n-1 \choose r-1} + {n-1 \choose r}(rn​)=(r−1n−1​)+(rn−1​)

Approach

  • Sort jobs in increasing order of finish time and relabel: f1≤f2≤...≤fnf_1 \leq f_2 \leq ... \leq f_nf1​≤f2​≤...≤fn​
  • Job iii comes before job jjj if i<ji < ji<j

  • p(j)p(j)p(j) is the largest index i<ji < ji<j such that job iii is compatible with job jjj

    • p(j)=0p(j) = 0p(j)=0 if there is no such job iii
    • All jobs that come before p(j)p(j)p(j) are also compatible with job jjj

Sub-problems

  • Let OOO be the optimal solution: it contains a subset of the input jobs. Two cases to consider:

    • Case 1: Job nnn is not in OOO.

      • OOO must be the optimal solution for jobs {1,2,...,n−1}\{1, 2, ..., n - 1\}{1,2,...,n−1}

    • Case 2: Job nnn is in OOO

      • OOO cannot use incompatible jobs {p(n)+1,p(n)+2,...,n−1}\{p(n) + 1, p(n) + 2, ..., n - 1\}{p(n)+1,p(n)+2,...,n−1}
      • Remaining jobs in OOO must be the optimal solution for jobs {1,2,...,p(n)}\{1, 2, ..., p(n)\}{1,2,...,p(n)}
    • One of the two cases must be true: OOO is the best of the two choices
    • Suggests finding optimal solution for sub-problems consisting of jobs {1,2,...,j−1,j}\{1, 2, ..., j - 1, j\}{1,2,...,j−1,j}, for all values of jjj

Basic Outline of Dynamic Programming

  • need a collection of sub-problems that satisfy a few properties
  • There are a polynomial number of sub problems
  • The solution to the problem can by computed easily from the solutions to the sub problems
  • There is a natural ordering from "smallest" to "largest"
  • There is an easy to compute recurrence that allows us to compute the solution to the sub-problems from solutions to some smaller sub problems

Least Squares Problem

  • Given a set of scientific or statistical data plotted on two axes, find the best line that passes through these points
  • Instance: Set P={(x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xn,yn)}P = \{(x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), ... , (x_n, y_n)\}P={(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xn​,yn​)} of nnn points
  • Solution: Line L:y=ax+bL: y = ax + bL:y=ax+b that minimizes Error(L,P) =∑i=1n(yi−axi−b)2= \displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - ax_i - b)^2=i=1∑n​(yi​−axi​−b)2

  • How many unknown paramters must we find values for?

    • a,ba,ba,b via lagrangian
    • a=n∑xiyi−(∑xi)(∑yi)n∑xi2−(∑xi)2a = \frac{n\sum x_i y_i - (\sum x_i)(\sum y_i)}{n \sum x_i^2 - (\sum x_i)^2}a=n∑xi2​−(∑xi​)2n∑xi​yi​−(∑xi​)(∑yi​)​ and b=∑yi−a∑xinb = \frac{\sum y_i - a \sum x_i}{n}b=n∑yi​−a∑xi​​

Segmented Least Squares

  • Want to fit multiple lines through PPP
  • Each line must fit contiguus set of x-coordinates
  • Lines must minimize total error
  • Divide the points into segments; each segment contains a consecutive set of points ordered by increasing x-coordinate
  • Instance: Set P={pi=(xi,yi),1≤i≤n}P = \{p_i = (x_i, y_i), 1 \leq i \leq n\}P={pi​=(xi​,yi​),1≤i≤n} of nnn points, x1<x2<...<xnx_1 < x_2 < ... < x_nx1​<x2​<...<xn​ and a parameter C>0C > 0C>0

  • Solution

    • an integer kkk
    • a partition of PPP into kkk segments {P1,P2,...,Pk}\{P_1, P_2, ..., P_k\}{P1​,P2​,...,Pk​}
    • for each segment PjP_jPj​, the best fit line Lj:y=ajx+bj,1≤j≤kL_j: y = a_jx + b_j, 1 \leq j \leq kLj​:y=aj​x+bj​,1≤j≤k that minimises the total error ∑j=1kError(Lj,Pj)+Ck\displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^k Error(L_j, P_j) + Ckj=1∑k​Error(Lj​,Pj​)+Ck
  • if CCC is very large then one line works, if CCC is small, then we fit many lines
  • How many unknown parameters here? 2k,k2k, k2k,k since we need to find the slope and intercept of kkk lines as well a the optimal value of kkk itself

Formulating the Recursion

  • Let eje_jej​ deonte the minmium error of a (single) line that fits {p1,p2,...,pi}\{p_1, p_2, ..., p_i\}{p1​,p2​,...,pi​}
  • Let OPT(i)OPT(i)OPT(i) be the optimal total error for the points {p1,p2,...,pi}\{p_1, p_2, ..., p_i\}{p1​,p2​,...,pi​}

  • Observation: Where does the last segment in the optimal solution end? pnp_npn​, and this segment starts at some point pip_ipi​. So the rest of the solution must be the optimal fit for points up to pip_ipi​: OPT(i−1)OPT(i-1)OPT(i−1)
  • OPT(n)OPT(n)OPT(n) is the error for the line that goes through points i,ni, ni,n plus the penalty for adding a line CCC plus the best solution for the last i−1i-1i−1 points

RNA Molecules

  • basic biolegical molecule. Single stranded
  • RNA molecules fold into complex "secondary structures"
  • Secondary structure governs the behavior of an RNA molecule
  • carious rules govern secondary structure formation
  • Pairs of bases match up; each base matches with ≤ 1 other base
  • Adenine : Uracil
  • Cytosine : Guanine
  • There are no kinks in the folded molecule
  • Structures are "knot-free"
  • High level problem: given an RNA molecule, predict its secondary structure

Formulating the Problem

  • an RNA Molecule is a string B=b1b2...bnB = b_1 b_2 ... b_nB=b1​b2​...bn​; each bi∈{A,C,G,U}b_i \in \{A, C, G, U\}bi​∈{A,C,G,U}

  • A secondary structure on BBB is a set of pairs S={(i,j)}S = \{(i,j)\}S={(i,j)} where 1≤i,j≤n1 \leq i,j \leq n1≤i,j≤n and

    • No kinks: if (i,j)∈S(i,j) \in S(i,j)∈S then i<j−4i < j - 4i<j−4
    • Watson Crick: The elements in each pair of SSS consist of either {A,U}\{A, U\}{A,U} or {c,G}\{c, G\}{c,G}
    • SSS is a matching: no index appears in more than one pair
    • No knots: If (i,j)(i, j)(i,j) and (k,l)(k, l)(k,l) are two pairs in SSS, then we cannot have i<k<j<li < k < j < li<k<j<l
  • The Energy of a secondary structure ∝\propto∝ the number of base pairs in it.
  • Problem: Compute the largest secondary structure, i.e. with the largest number of base pairs

Dynamic Programming Approach

  • OPT(j)OPT(j)OPT(j) is the maximum number of base pairs in a secondary structure for b1b2...bjb_1b_2...b_jb1​b2​...bj​, OP(j)=0,j≤5OP(j) = 0, j \leq 5OP(j)=0,j≤5

  • In the optimal secondary structure on b1b2...bjb_1b_2...b_jb1​b2​...bj​

    • If jjj is not a member of any pair, use OPT(j−1)OPT(j-1)OPT(j−1)

    • If jjj pairs with some t<j−4t < j - 4t<j−4, then the knot condition yields tow independent sub-problems: OPT(t−1)OPT(t-1)OPT(t−1), ???

      • Note that we need that sub-problems to be indexed by both start and by end
  • OPT(i,j)OPT(i,j)OPT(i,j) is the maximum number of base pairs in a secondary structure for bibi+1...bjb_ib_{i+1}...b_jbi​bi+1​...bj​, OPT(i,j)=0,i≥j−4OPT(i,j) = 0, i \geq j-4OPT(i,j)=0,i≥j−4

  • In the optimal secondary structure on bibi+2...bjb_ib_{i+2}...b_jbi​bi+2​...bj​

    • If jjj is not a member of any pair, compute OPT(i,j−1)OPT(i, j-1)OPT(i,j−1)
    • If jjj pairs with somme t<j−4t < j -4t<j−4, compute OPT(i,t−1)OPT(i, t-1)OPT(i,t−1) and OPT(t+1,j−1)OPT(t+1, j-1)OPT(t+1,j−1)

OPT(i,j)=max⁡(OPT(i,j−1),max⁡t(1+OPT(i,t−1)+OPT(t+1,j−1)))OPT(i,j) = \max \Big( OPT(i, j-1), \max \limits_t (1 + OPT(i, t-1) + OPT(t+1, j-1)) \Big)OPT(i,j)=max(OPT(i,j−1),tmax​(1+OPT(i,t−1)+OPT(t+1,j−1)))

  • In the "inner" maximisation, ttt runs over all indices between i,j−5i,j-5i,j−5 that are allowed to pair with jjj

Dynamic Programming for Shortest Path

Motivation

  • Computational finance

    • Each node is a financial agent
    • The cost cuvc_{uv}cuv​ of an edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) is the cost of a transaction in which we buy from agent uuu and sell to agent vvv
    • Negative cost corresponds to profit

  • Internet routing protocols

    • Dijkstra's algorithm needs knowledge of the entire network
    • Routers only know which other routers they are connected to
    • Algorithm for shortest paths with negative edges is decentralized
    • Not covered in class, but described in Chapter 6.9

Problem Statement

  • Input: a directed graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E) with a cost function c:E→Rc: E \rightarrow \realsc:E→R i.e., cuvc_{uv}cuv​ is the cost of the edge (u,v)∈E(u,v) \in E(u,v)∈E
  • A negative cycle is a directed graph whose edges have a total cost that is negative

  • Two related problems:

    • If GGG has no negative cycles, find the shortest s-t path: a path from source sss to destination ttt with minimum total cost
    • Does GGG have a negative cycle?

Approaches for Shortest Path Algorithm

  1. Dijkstra's
  2. Computes incorrect answers because it is greedy
  3. Add some largest constant to each edge
  4. Computes incorrect answers because the minimum cost path changes

DP Approach

  • Assume GGG has no negative cycles
  • Claim: there is a shortest path from sss to ttt that is simple (does not repeat a node) and therefore has at most n−1n-1n−1 edges

  • How do we define sub-problems?

    • Proof: The portion of the s→ts \rightarrow ts→t path between the two appearances of the node uuu must have a positive cost
    • Shortest s→ts \rightarrow ts→t path has ≤n−1\leq n -1≤n−1 edges: how can we reach ttt using iii edges, for different values of iii?
    • We do not know which nodes will be in shortest s→ts \rightarrow ts→t path: how we can reach ttt from each node in VVV
  • Sub-problems defined by varying the number of edges in the shortest path and by varying the starting node in the shortest path

DP Recursion

  • OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v): minimum cost of a v→tv \rightarrow tv→t path that uses at most iii edges
  • ttt is not explicitly mentioned in the sub-problems
  • Goal is to compute OPT(n−1,s)OPT(n - 1, s)OPT(n−1,s)

  • Let PPP be the optimal path whose cost is OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)OPT(i,v)

    • If PPP actually uses i−1i -1i−1 edges, then OPT(i,v)=OPT(i−v)OPT(i,v) = OPT(i - v)OPT(i,v)=OPT(i−v)
    • If first node on PPP is www, then OPT(i,v)=cvw+OPT(i−1,wOPT(i,v) = c_{vw} + OPT(i -1, wOPT(i,v)=cvw​+OPT(i−1,w
OPT(0,v)={0;v=t∞;v≠t OPT(0, v) = \begin{cases} 0; v = t \\ \infty; v \neq t \end{cases}OPT(0,v)={0;v=t∞;v​=t​

OPT(i,v)=min⁡(OPT(i−v),min⁡w∈V(cvw+OPT(i−1,w)))OPT(i,v) = \min \Big(OPT(i-v), \min \limits_{w \in V} (c_{vw} + OPT(i -1, w)) \Big)OPT(i,v)=min(OPT(i−v),w∈Vmin​(cvw​+OPT(i−1,w)))

10 - Network Flow

Motivation

  • Fundemental problems in combinatorial optimization
  • duality between flow and cuts

Flow Networks

  • Use directed graphs to model transport networks:

    • edges carry traffic and have capacities
    • nodes act as switches
    • source nodes generate traffic, sink nodes absorb traffic

  • A flow network is a directed graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E)

    • each edge e∈Ee \in Ee∈E has a capacity c(e)>0c(e) > 0c(e)>0
    • There is a single source node s∈Vs \in Vs∈V
    • There is a single sink node s∈Vs \in Vs∈V
    • Nodes other than s,ts,ts,t are internal

Defining Flow

  • In a flow network G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E), an s−ts-ts−t flow is a function f:E→R+f: E \rightarrow \Reals^+f:E→R+ such that:

    • (Capacity conditions) for each e inE,0≤f(e)≤c(e)e \ in E, 0 \leq f(e) \leq c(e)e inE,0≤f(e)≤c(e)
    • (Conservation conditions) for each internal node vvv, ∑e into Vf(e)=∑e out of Vf(e)\displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ into } V} f(e) = \displaystyle\sum_{e \text{ out of } V} f(e)e into V∑​f(e)=e out of V∑​f(e)
  • The value of a flow is v(f)=∑e out of f(e)v(f) = \sum_{e \text{ out of } } f(e)v(f)=∑e out of ​f(e)

Maximum-Flow Problem

  • Instance: a flow network GGG
  • Solution: The flow with the largest value in GGG, where the maximum is taking over all possible flows on GGG
  • Output should assign a flow value to each edge in the graph
  • The flow on each edge should satisfy the capacity condition
  • The flow into and out of each internal node should satisfy the conservation conditions
  • the value of the output flow, i.e., the total flow out of the source node in the output flow, must be the largest possible over all possible flows in GGG

  • Assumptions:

    • Node edges enter sss, no edges leave ttt
    • There is at least one edge incident on each node
    • all edge capacities are integers

Developing the Algorithm

  • No known DP algorithm

  • Greedy approach instead

    • Start with zero flow along all edges
    • find an s−ts-ts−t path and push as much flow along it as possible
    • idea is to increase flow: push flow along edges with leftover capacity and undow flow along edges already carrying flow

Residual graph

  • Give a flow network G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E) and a flow fff on GGG, the residual graph GfG_fGf​ of GGG w.r.t. fff is a directed graph such that:

    • (Nodes) GfG_fGf​ has the same nodes as GGG
    • (Forward edges) for each edge e=(u,v)∈Ee = (u,v) \in Ee=(u,v)∈E s.t. f(e)<c(e)f(e) < c(e)f(e)<c(e), GfG_fGf​ contains the edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) with a residual capacity c(e)−f(e)c(e) - f(e)c(e)−f(e)
    • (Backward edges) for each edge e∈Ee \in Ee∈E s.t. f(e)>0f(e) > 0f(e)>0, GfG_fGf​ contains the edge e′=(u,v)e' = (u,v)e′=(u,v) with a residual capacity

Max-Flow Min-Cut Theorem

  • The flow f‾\overline ff​ computed by the Ford-Faulkerson algorithm is a maximum flow
  • Given a flow of maximum value, we can compute a minimum s−ts-ts−t cut in O(m)O(m)O(m) time
  • In every flow network, there is a flow fff and a cut (A,B)(A,B)(A,B) such that v(f)=c(A,B)v(f) = c(A,B)v(f)=c(A,B)
  • Max-Flow Min-Cut Theorem: in every flow network, the maximum value of an s−ts-ts−t flow is equal to the minimum capacity of an s−ts-ts−t cut
  • Corollary: If all capacities in a flow network are integers, then there is a maximum flow fff where f(e)f(e)f(e), the value of the flow on edge eee, is an integer for every edge e∈Ge \in Ge∈G

Real-Valued Capacities

  • If capacities are real-valued, Ford-Faulkerson algorithm may not terminate!
  • But Max-Flow Min-Cut theorem is still true, why?

Improving Ford-Faulkerson Algorithm

  • Bad case for Ford-Faulkerson is when the bottleneck edge is the augmenting path has a low capacity
  • Idea: decrease number of iterations by picking s−ts-ts−t path with bottleneck edge of largest capacity. Computing this path can slow down each iteration considerably.
  • Modified idea: Maintain a scaling parameter Δ\DeltaΔ and choose only augmenting paths with bottleneck capacity at least Δ\DeltaΔ
  • Gf(Δ)G_f(\Delta)Gf​(Δ): residual network restricted to edges with residual capacities ≥Δ\geq \Delta≥Δ

11 - Network Flow Applications

Maximum Flow and Minimum Cut Problems

Matching in Bipartite Graphs

  • Bipartite Graph a graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) where

    • V=X∪Y,X,YV = X \cup Y, X,YV=X∪Y,X,Y are disjoint and
    • E⊆X×YE \subseteq X \times YE⊆X×Y
  • Bipartite graphs model situations in which objects are matched with or assigned to other objects: e.g. marraiges, residents/hospitals, jobs/machines
  • A Matching in a bipartite graph GGG is a set M⊆M \subseteqM⊆ of edges such that each node of VVV is incident on at most edge of MMM
  • A set of edges MMM is a perfect matching if every node in VVV is incident on exactly one edge in MMM
  • Instance: A bipartite graph GGG
  • Solution: The matching of largest size in GGG

Algorithm for Bipartite Graph Matching

  • Convert GGG to a flow network G′G'G′: direct edges from XXX to YYY, add nodes sss and ttt connect sss to each node in XXX and ttt to each node in yyy, set all edge capacities to 1
  • Computer the maximum flow in G′G'G′
  • Convert the maximum flow in G′G'G′ into a matching in GGG
  • Claim: the value of the maximum flow in G′G'G′ equals the size of hte maximum matching in GGG
  • In general, there is a matching of size kkk in GGG if an only if there is a (integer valued) flow of kkk in G′G'G′

Strategy for Proving Correctness

  • Preclude the possibilities that G′G'G′ has a flow of value kkk but we cannot construct a matching in GGG with kkk edges
  • Matching => flow: if there is a matching with kkk edges in GGG, there is an s−ts-ts−t flow of value kkk in G′G'G′

  • How do we construct this flow?

    • Consider every edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) in the matching: u∈X,v∈Yu \in X, v \in Yu∈X,v∈Y
    • Send on unit of flow along the path s→u→v→ts \rightarrow u \rightarrow v \rightarrow ts→u→v→t

  • Why have we constructed a flow

    • Capacity constraint: No edges receive a flow >1> 1>1 because we started with a matching
    • Conservation constraint: Every node other than sss and ttt has one incoming unit and one outgoing unit of flow because we started with a matching
  • What is the value of the flow? kkk, since exactly that many nodes out of sss carry flow

Now let us consider the reverse side of the reduction

  • Flow => matching: if there is a flow f′f'f′ in G′G'G′ with value kkk, there is a matching MMM in GGG with kkk edges

    • There is an integer-valued flow f′f'f′ of value k  ⟹  k \impliesk⟹ flow along any edge is 0 or 1
    • Let MMM be the set of edges not incident on sss or ttt with flow equal to 1
    • Claim: MMM contains kkk edges
    • Claim Each node in XXX (respectively, YYY) is the tail (respectively, head) of at most one edge in MMM
  • Conclusion: size of the maximum matching in GGG is equal to the value of the maximum flow in G′G'G′: the edges in this matching are those that carry flow from XXX to YYY in G′G'G′

In general, we must prove that the reduction is bi-directional, or isomorphic

Running time of Bipartite Graph Matching Algorithm

  • Suppose GGG has mmm edges in nnn nodes in XXX, and in YYY
  • C≤nC \leq nC≤n
  • Ford-Fulkerson algorithm runs in O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) time
  • How do we determine if a bipartite graph GGG has a perfect matching? Find the maximum matching and check if it is perfect
  • Suppose GGG has no perfect matching. Can we exhibit a short "certificate" of that fact? What can such certificates look like?
  • GGG has no perfect matching iff there is a cut in G′G'G′ with capacity less than nnn. Therefore, the cut is a certificate

  • We would like the certificate in terms of GGG

    • For example, two nodes in YYY with on incident edge each with the same neighbor in XXX
    • Generally, a subset S⊆XS \subseteq XS⊆X with neighbors Γ(A)⊆Y\Gamma (A) \subseteq YΓ(A)⊆Y, such that ∣A∣<∣Γ(A)∣|A| < |\Gamma(A)|∣A∣<∣Γ(A)∣

Then GGG either has a perfect matching or there is a subset A⊆YA \subseteq YA⊆Y such that ∣A∣>∣Γ(A)∣|A| > | \Gamma (A) |∣A∣>∣Γ(A)∣. Edge-Disjoint Paths

  • A set of paths in a directed graph GGG is edge disjoint if each edge in GGG appears in at most one path
  • Instance: Directed graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E) with two distinguished nodes s,ts,ts,t
  • Solution: The maximum number of edge-disjoiint paths between sss and ttt

Mapping to the Max-Flow Problem

  • Convert GGG into a flow network with edge capacities of 1
  • Claim: There are kkk edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths from in a directed graph GGG if and only if there is a s−ts-ts−t flow in GGG with value ≥k\geq k≥k
  • Paths => flow: if there are kkk edge-disjoint paths from sss to ttt, send one unit of flowin along each to yield a flow with value kkk

  • Flow => paths: Suppose there is an integer-valued flow of value at least kkk. Are there kkk edge-disjoint paths? If so, what are they?

    • There is an integral flow. Therefore flow on each edge is 0, or 1
    • Claim: if fff is a 0-1 value flow of value v(f)=kv(f) = kv(f)=k, the the set of edges with flow f(e)=1f(e) = 1f(e)=1 contains a set of kkk edge-disjoint paths

  • But how do we show that this set of edges with flow value of 1 actually form paths?

    • Claim if fff is a 0−10-10−1 valued flow of value v(f)=kv(f) = kv(f)=km then the set of edges with flow f(e)=1f(e) = 1f(e)=1 contains a set of kkk edge-disjoint paths

  • Prove by induction on the number of edges in fff that carry flow. Let this number be κ(f)\kappa(f)κ(f).

    • Base case: v=0v = 0v=0. Nothing to prove

    • Inductive Hypothesis: For every flow f′f'f′ in GGG with

      • value v(f′)<kv(f') < kv(f′)<k carrying flow on κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f) edges or
      • value v(f′)=kv(f') = kv(f′)=k carrying flow on κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f) edges, the set of edges with f′(e)=1f'(e) = 1f′(e)=1 contains a set of v(f′)v(f')v(f′) edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths
    • Inductive Step: Construct a set of kkk s−ts-ts−t paths from fff. Work out by hand
  • Note: formulating the inductive hypothesis can be trick
  • Strategy is to prove the inductive step first

  • During this proof, we observe two types of "smaller" flows:

    • When you succeed in finding an s−ts-ts−t path, we get a new flow f′f'f′ that is smaller, i.e. v(f′)<kv(f') < kv(f′)<k carrying flow on fewer edges, i.e. κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f)
    • When we run into a cycle, we get a new flow f′f'f′ with v(f′)=kv(f') = kv(f′)=k but carrying flow on fewer edges, i.e. κ(f′)<κ(f)\kappa (f') < \kappa (f)κ(f′)<κ(f)
  • We combine both situations in the inductive hypothesis

Certificate for Edge-Disjoint Paths Algorithm

  • A set F⊆EF \subseteq EF⊆E of edges separatees s,ts,ts,t if the graph (V,E−F)(V, E-F)(V,E−F) contains no s−ts-ts−t paths
  • Menger's Theorem: In every directed graph with nodes s,ts,ts,t, the maximum number of edge disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths is equal to the minimum number of edges whose removal disconnes sss from ttt.

Running Time of the Edge-Disjoint Paths Algorithm

  • Given a flow of value kkk, how quickly can we determine the kkk edge-disjoint paths? O(mn)O(mn)O(mn)
  • Corollary: The Ford-Fulkerson algorithm can be used to find a maximum set of edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths in a directed graph GGG in O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) time.

Edge-Disjoint Paths in Undirected Graphs

  • Can extend the theorem to undirected graphs
  • Replace each edge with two directed edges of capacity 1 and apply the algorithm for directed graphs

  • Problem: Both counterparts of an undirected edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) may be used by differnt edge-disjoint paths on the directed graph

    • resolved by zeroing out flow for edges where flow goes in both directions
  • Can obtain an integral flow where only one of the directed counterparts of (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) has non-zero flow
  • We can find the maximum number of edge disjoint paths in O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) time
  • We can prove a version of Menger's theorem for undirected graphs: in every undirected graph with nodes s,ts,ts,t, the maximum number of edge-disjoint s−ts-ts−t paths is equal to the minimum number of edges whose removal separates sss from ttt

Image Segmentation

  • Fundemental problem in computer vision: segmentaing an image into coherent regions
  • A basic segmentation problem is that of partitioning an image into a foreground and a background: label each pixel in the image as belonging to one of those two
  • Let VVV be the set of pixels in an image
  • Let EEE be the set of pairs of neighboring pixels
  • VVV and EEE yield an undirected graph G(V,E)G(V,E)G(V,E)
  • Each pixel iii has a likelihood ai>0a_i > 0ai​>0 that it belongs to the foreground and a likelihood bib_ibi​ that it belongs to the background
  • These likelihoods are specified in the input to the problem
  • We want to fg/bg boundary to be smooth: for each pait (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) of pixels, there is a separation penalty pij≥0p_{ij} \geq 0pij​≥0 for placing one of them in the foreground and the other in the background

  • Solution: Optimum labelling: partition of the pixels into two sets A,BA,BA,B that maximizes
q(A,B)=∑i∈Aai+∑j∈Bbi−∑(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1pij\begin{aligned} q(A,B) &= \displaystyle\sum_{i \in A} a_i + \displaystyle\sum_{j \in B} b_i - \displaystyle\sum_{ (i,j) \in E |A \cap \{i,j\}|=1 } p_{ij} \end{aligned}q(A,B)​=i∈A∑​ai​+j∈B∑​bi​−(i,j)∈E∣A∩{i,j}∣=1∑​pij​​

  • Differences:

    • Maximizing an objective function rather than minimizing

    • We have values on the nodes
    • The graph is undirected

Solving the Other Issues

  • Solve the other issues like we did earlier:

    • Add a new "super-sink" ttt to represent the background

    • Direct edges away from sss and into ttt

12 - NP and Computational Intractibility

  • N=1,P=0N = 1, P = 0N=1,P=0

Algorithm Design

  • Patterns:

    • Greed O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) interval scheduling
    • Divide and Conquer O(nlog⁡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn) counting inversions
    • Dynamic Programmming O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3) RNA folding
    • Duality: O(n2m)O(n^2 m)O(n2m) maximum flow and minimum cuts
    • Reductions
    • Local search
    • Randomization

  • Anti-Patterns

    • NP-completeness: O(nk)O(n^k)O(nk) algorithm unlikely
    • PSPACE-completeness: O(nk)O(n^k)O(nk) certification algorithm unlikely
    • Undecidability: no algorithm possible

Computational Tractability

  • When is an algorithm an efficient solution to a problem? When the running time is polynomial in the size of the input
  • A problem is computationally tractable if it has a polynomial time algorithm solution
Polynomial time Probably not
Shortest path Longest Path
Matching 3D Matching
Min cut Max cut
2-SAT 3 SAT
Planar four-color Planar 3 color
Bipartite vertex cover vertex cover
Primarily testing Factoring

Problem Classification

  • Classify problems based on whether they admit efficient solutions or not
  • Some extremely hard problems cannot be solved efficiently (e.g. chess on an n×nn \times nn×n board)
  • However, classification is unclear for a large number of problems
  • We can prove that these problems are fundementally equivalent and are manifestations of the same problem!

Polynomial-Time Reduction

  • Goal is to express statements of the type: "Problem X is at least as hard as problem Y"
  • Use the notion of reductions

  • Y is polynomial-time reducible to XXX (Y≤PX)(Y \leq_P X)(Y≤P​X) if any arbitrary instance (input) of YYY can be solved using a polynomial number of standard operations, plus one call to a black box that solves problem XXX

    • Maximum Bipartite Matching ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Maxmum s−ts-ts−t Flow

      • Maximum Bipartite Matching ≰P\nleq_P≰P​ Maxmum s−ts-ts−t Flow because you can't reduce a network flow to a bipartite matching...
      • You can get 4 from 3 by adding 1, but you can't get 3 from 4 by adding 1
    • Image Segmentation ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Minimum s−ts-ts−t Cut
    • ≤P=\leq_P =≤P​= polynomial time reducable
  • Y≤PXY \leq_P XY≤P​X implies that "XXX is at least as hard as YYY"
  • Such reductions are Karp reductions. Cook reductions allow a polynomial number of calls to the black box that solves XXX

Usefulness of Reductions

  • Claim: If Y≤PXY \leq_P XY≤P​X and XXX can be solved in polynomial time, then YYY can be solved in polynomial time
  • Contrapositive: If Y≤PXY \leq_P XY≤P​X and YYY cannot be solved in polynomial time, then XXX cannot be solved in polynomial time
  • Informally: If YYY is hard, and we can show that YYY reduces to XXX, then the hardness "spreads" to XXX

Reduction Strategies

  • Simple equivalence
  • Special case to general case
  • Encoding with gadgets

Optimisiation versus Decision Problems

  • So far, we have developed algorithms that solve optimisation problems

    • Compute the largest flow
    • Find the closest pair of points
    • Find the schedule with the least completion time
  • Now, we turn our attention to decision versions of problems, e.g. is there a flow with value at least kkk, for a given value of kkk
  • Decision problem: answer to every input is yes or no

  • Instance: A natural number nnn
  • Question: Is nnn prime?

Independent Set and Vertex Cover

  • Given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E), a subset S⊆VS \subseteq VS⊆V is an independent set if no two vertices in SSS are connected by an edge

  • Given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E), a subset S⊆VS \subseteq VS⊆V is a vertex cover if every edge in EEE is incident on at least one vertex in SSS

  • Goal: Demonstrate a simple equivalence between these two problems
  • Claim: Independent Set ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Vertex Cover and Vertex Cover ≤P\leq_P≤P​ Independent Set
  • N.B. the inverse of an independent set must be a vertex cover

  • From G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and kkk, create an instance of VC: an undirected graph G′=(V′,E′)G'=(V', E')G′=(V′,E′) and an integer k′k'k′

    • This proof is an iff because we're using a blackbox algorithm for VC to solve IS

      • If the black box finds a vertex cover of size ≤k′\leq k'≤k′, we must be sure we can construct an independent set of size ≥k\geq k≥k from this vertex cover

Vertex Cover and Set Cover

  • IS is a "packing" problem: pack as many vertices as possible, subject to constraints (the edges)
  • VC is a "covering" problem: cover all edges in the graph with as few vertices as possible

SAT and 3-SAT

  • Instance: A set of clauses C1,C2,...,CkC_1, C_2, ..., C_kC1​,C2​,...,Ck​, each of length 3, over a set X={x1,x2,...,xn}X = \{ x_1, x_2, ..., x_n\}X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​} of nnn variables

  • SAT and 3-SAT are fundemental combinatorial search problems
  • We have to make nnn independent decisions (the assignments for each variable) while satisfying the set constrains
  • Satisfying each constraint in isolation is easy, but we have to make our decision so that all constraints are satisfied simultanesouly

Finding vs. Certifying

  • Is it easy to check if a given set of vertices in an undirected graph forms an independent set of size at least kkk
  • Is it east to check if a particular truth assignment satisfies a set of clauses?
  • We draw a contrast between finding a solution and checking a solution (in polynomial time)
  • Since we have not been able to develop efficient algorithms to solve many decision problems, let us turn our attention to whether we can check if a proposed solution is correct

Problems and Algorithms

Primes

  • Instance: A natural number nnn
  • Question: Is nnn prime?
  • Decision problem XXX: for every input sss answer X(s)X(s)X(s) is yes or no
  • An algorithm AAA for a decision problem receives an input sss and returns A(S)∈{yes,no}A(S) \in \{ yes, no \}A(S)∈{yes,no}

  • An algorithm AAA solves the problem XXX if for every input sss

    • if X(s)=yesX(s) = yesX(s)=yes then A(s)=yesA(s) = yesA(s)=yes and
    • if X(s)=noX(s) = noX(s)=no then A(s)=noA(s) = noA(s)=no

  • AAA has a polynomial running time if there is a polynomial function p(∙)p(\bullet)p(∙) such that for every input sss, AAA terminates on sss in at most O(p(∣s∣)O(p(|s|)O(p(∣s∣) steps

    • There is an algorithm such that p(∣s∣)=∣s∣12p(|s|) = |s|^{12}p(∣s∣)=∣s∣12 for the Primes problem, improved to ∣s∣6|s|^6∣s∣6
  • P\mathcal PP: is a set of problems XXX for which there is a polynomial time algorithm
  • A decision problem XXX is in P\mathcal PP iff there is an algorithm AAA with polynomial running time that solves XXX

Efficient Certification

  • A "checking" algorithm for a decision problem XXX has a different structure from an algorithm that solves XXX
  • Checking an algorithm needs input sss as well as a separate "certificate" ttt that contain evidence that X(s)=yesX(s) = yesX(s)=yes

  • An algorithm BBB is an efficient certifier for a problem XXX if

    • BBB is a polynomial time algorithm that takes two inputs s,ts,ts,t and

    • for all inputs sss:

      • X(s)=yesX(s) = yesX(s)=yes iff there is a certificate ttt such that B(s,t)=yesB(s,t) = yesB(s,t)=yes, and
      • the size of ttt is polynomial in the size of sss
  • Certifier's job is to take a candidate certificate ttt that s∈Xs \in Xs∈X and check in polynomial time whether ttt is a correct certififcate
  • Certificate ttt must be "short" so that certifier can run in polynomial time
  • Certifier does not care about how to find these certificates

NP\mathcal {NP}NP

  • P\mathcal PP: Set of problems XXX for which there is a polynomial time algorithm
  • NP\mathcal NPNP: Set of all problems for which there exists an efficient certifier

  • 3-SAT ∈P\in \mathcal P∈P

    • Certificate ttt: a truth assignment to the variables
    • Certifier BBB: checks whether the assignment causes every clause to evaluate to true

  • Independent set ∈P\in \mathcal P∈P

    • Certificate ttt: a set of at least kkk vertices
    • Certifier BBB: checks that no pair of vertices are connected by an edge

  • Set Cover ∈P\in \mathcal P∈P:

    • Certificate ttt: a list of kkk sets from the collection
    • Certifier BBB: checks if the union of these sets is UUU

P\mathcal {P}P vs. NP\mathcal {NP}NP

  • Claim: P⊆NP\mathcal{P} \subseteq \mathcal{NP}P⊆NP

    • Let XXX be any problem in \mathcal{P}
    • There is a polynomial time algorithm AAA that solves XXX

    • BBB ignores ttt and simply returns A(s)A(s)A(s). Why is BBB an efficient certifier

      • BBB just has to check the certificate, not compute it
  • Is P=NP\mathcal{P} = \mathcal{NP}P=NP or is NP−P≠0\mathcal{NP} - \mathcal{P} \neq 0NP−P​=0. Major unsolved problem in CS

NP\mathcal {NP}NP-Complete and NP\mathcal {NP}NP-Hard problems

Circuit Satisfiability

  • Cook-Levin Theorem: Circuit Satisfiability is NP\mathcal NPNP-Complete

  • A circuit KKK is a labelled, directed acyclic graph such that

    • the sources in KKK are labelled with constants (0 or 1) or the name of a distinct variable (the inputs of the circuit)
    • every other node is labeled with one Boolean operator ∧,∨,¬\land, \lor, \neg∧,∨,¬
    • a single node with not outgoing edges represents the output of KKK
  • Instance: A circuit KKK
  • Question: Is there a truth assignment to the inputs that causes the output to have value 1?

14 - Coping with NP-Completeness

  • These problems come up in real life

  • NP\mathcal{NP}NP-Complete means that a problem is hard to solve in the worse case. Can we come up with better solutions at least in some cases?

    • Develop algorithms that are exponential in one parameter in the problem
    • Consider special cases of the input e.g. graphs that "look like" trees
    • Develop algorithms that can provably compute a solution close to the optimal

Vertex Cover

  • Instance: Undirected graph GGG and an integer kkk
  • Question: Does GGG contain a vertex cover of size at most kkk?
  • Problem has two parameters: k,nk,nk,n
  • What is the running time of a brute force algorithm: O(kn(nk))=O(knk+1)O(kn {n \choose k}) = O(kn^{k+1})O(kn(kn​))=O(knk+1)

  • Can we devise an algorithm whose running time is exponential in kkk but polynomial in nnn e.g. O(2kn)O(2^kn)O(2kn)

    • Fixed parameter tractable

Designing the Vertex Cover Algorithm

  • Intuition: if a graph has a small Vertex Cover, it cannot have too many edges
  • Claim: If GGG has nnn nodes and GGG has a vertex cover of size at most kkk, then GGG has at most knknkn edges
  • Easy part of algorithm: Return no if GGG has more than knknkn edges
  • G−{u}G - \{ u \}G−{u} is the graph GGG w/o the node uuu and the edge incident on uuu

  • Consier an edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v). Either uuu or vvv must be in the vertex cover

    • Claim: GGG has a vertex cover of size at most kkk iff for any edge (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) either G−{u}G - \{ u \}G−{u} or G−{v}G - \{ v \}G−{v} has a vertex cover of size at most k−1k-1k−1

Analysing the Vertex Cover Algorithm

  • Develop a recurrence relation for the algorithm with parameters
  • Let T(n,k)T(n,k)T(n,k) denote the worst-case running time of the algorithm on an instance of Vertex Cover with parameters n,kn,kn,k
  • T(n,1)≤cnT(n, 1) \leq cnT(n,1)≤cn

  • Claim: T(n,k)=O(2kkn)T(n,k) = O(2^kkn)T(n,k)=O(2kkn)
